Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Initial Appearance as to Jeniffer Torres-Diaz held on 9/15/2011. Present were SAUSA Cesar Rivera and Mr. Gary Montilla. Defendant was provided with copy of the indictment and advised as to the charges and her rights. Per the Government's request, and upon information provided by Probation, the Court appointed Mr. Gary Montilla through the CJA Panel to represent defendant, due to defendant's medical condition. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Reopening of Bail Hearing as to Moises Hernandez-Vachier held on 3/9/2012. Present were AUSA Brian Kidd and Mr. Jose Barreto-Rampolla. Mr. Barreto stated that defendant had successfully completed his inpatient treatment program and were  requesting that conditions be modified so that he can continue with an outpatient treatment program and suggested conditions of release. AUSA Kidd stated that they had no objection to his release, but that a secured amount be imposed and if an unsecured amount was to be imposed, that one of his parents sign the unsecured portion. The Court imposed $7,500.00 as bail of which $2,500.00 are to be cash or secured and $5,000.00 unsecured with the signature of one of his parents, 10 working days to post, outpatient treatment program, he's not to reside or enter the Jardines de Ceiba housing project plus all other standard conditions of release. (Court Reporter -FTR.)Hearing set for 09:30.Hearing held at 09:44.Hearing ended at 09:50. Interpreter -Marie Hernandez. (yr) (Entered: 03/19/2012)

Joseph Boucher. Defendant was also present assisted by the Court Interpreter. Consent to Proceed before a U.S. Magistrate Judge in a Felony Case and Waiver of Right to Trial by Jury was accepted and filed in open Court. The defendant was found competent to plea. Plea entered by William Mercado-Rexach (14) as to Count 1 of the Indictment. ORDER granting 486 Motion to Continue as to Marshal H. Figueroa-Bratkowiski (31). However, it is first of all inappropriate to ask on a Saturday to continue a Monday morning hearing. Likewise, we find it very unlikely that counsel was informed of her state court obligations over the weekend. The motion should have been filed Friday at the very latest. It is moreover inappropriate to file for an extension and, in the absence of a court order, treat that motion as granted: scheduling is the prerogative of the Court, not the parties. Though we grant the motion, we also warn the parties to treat the Court's calendar with more respect going forward. The COP hearing is reset for 6/6/2012, at 9:00 a.m., in Courtroom 8, before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll.Signed by US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll on 6/4/2012. (NBB) (Entered: 06/04/2012)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Bond Revocation Hearing as to Orlando Herrera-Cruz held on 8/8/2012. Present were AUSA Myriam Fernandez, Mr. Ignacio Fernandez and PO G. Montanez. Defendant is present in court and he's under custody. Mr. Fernandez addressed the Court stating that while they were not contesting the allegations contained in the motion filed by Probation, he needed to explain what led to the same. Explanation heard from defense counsel. The Government expressed its concern as to defendant having been previously admonished as to importance of complying with his bail conditions. USPO Montanez answered questions posed by the Court as to the incident. After hearing all parties, the Court found no reason to revoke the bail previously imposed and ordered that defendant be released from custody under the same conditions of release,  admonishing him the importance of compliance with the same. The US Marshals present in Court were ordered to release defendant from custody. (Court Reporter - FTR.)Hearing set for 09:00.Hearing held at 10:20.Hearing ended at 10:31.Interpreter - Felix Toledo. (yr) (Entered: 08/08/2012)

ORDER denying without prejudice 849 Motion for Psychiatric Exam as to Carlos Delgado-Vazquez (15). Any requests for mental evaluation is to be submitted with a proposed form of Order, in strict compliance with 18 U.S.C.  4241 et seq., indicating the scope of the evaluation, whether psychological or psychiatric services are necessary, and if the information is to be used only by defense counsel, as well as the curriculum vitae of the physician, and proposed fees. This is intended to facilitate processing under Criminal Justice Act and allows for proper determination of whether said evaluation is to be paid by the Department of Justice, the Criminal Justice Act, or the defendant. IT IS SO ORDERED. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 1/10/2013. (om) (Entered: 01/10/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Daniel R. Dominguez:Motion Hearing as to Javier Morales-Andreu held on 7/30/2013 re 1029 MOTION Requesting Order filed by Javier Morales-Andreu. Present in Court were: AUSA Cesar Rivera, Attys Francisco Dolz & Ruben Cerezo. Defendant is U/C and present in court. The Court question was "Why the Court has jurisdiction?" Colloquy held between the Court, and defense attorneys. Thereafter the Court rule as follows: "All the motions relating to the Court providing a direct remedy deemed DENIED due to lack of exhaustion because the Court understands that this is not a case which would be covered under the exception which espoused by justice prior in the case of United States versus NGO, 126, 2378, 2393 which is the concurring opinion of justice prior stating that you do not have to exhaust because exhaustion is not absolute if enforcing the procedure would result in a total miscarriage of justice. That's at 42 USC Section 1997, subsection E, subsection A. That's where Judge (?), our former chief of the First Circuit states that. This comes from administrative law, and in administrative law, exhaustion is not absolute. Plea Agreement due by 8/13/2013. (Court Reporter Kelly Surina.)Hearing set for 01:30.Hearing held at 02:14.Hearing ended at 02:38.Interpreter Felix Toledo. (su) (Entered: 08/01/2013)

ORDER - Denied without prejudice Fed.R.Crim.P. 43 requires a defendant to be present in the courtroom for a plea. Moreover, Fed.R.Crim.P. 11(b)(1) requires that, before a court accepts a plea of guilty, the defendant may be placed under oath and the court must address defendant personally in open court. There is no procedural rule or other federal authority allowing a defendant charged with a felony to plead guilty or be sentenced by video teleconference. Defendant has cited no authority or jurisprudence that a felony plea may be taken by video teleconference from a location outside the prosecuting district. As such, defendant is granted five (5) days to inform the court of relevant authorities in which she is basing her request. Then after, the government is granted five (5) days to inform its position on defendant's request. 1089 Motion for Change of Plea as to Carmen A. Velez-Garcia (4). Signed by US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez-Rive on 9/27/13. (ljt) (Entered: 09/27/2013)

Munute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Daniel R. Dominguez: Sentencing held on 6/30/2015 for Javier Morales-Andreu (5). Present were: AUSA Cesar Rivera, Attorneys Francisco Dolz, Ruben Cerezo, Luis O. Rodriguez(local counsel) and USPO Michelle Acevedo. Defendant present U/C and assisted by the court interpreter. The Court ordered corrections to the PSI report. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment were heard on behalf of defendant. Defendants allocution was heard. The Court accepts the recommendation of the parties and will imposed concurrent sentence. Count(s) 1, IMPR: Two Hundred (200) Months, to be served concurrently with sentence imposed in CR-12-192(CCC), and to concurrently to the sententence imposed at the Fajardo Superior Court; SRT: Ten (10) years to be served concurrently with SRT imposed in CR-12-192 (CCC); SMA: $100.00; Count(s) 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, Dismissed. Defendant was advised of his right to appeal. (Court Reporter Donna Prather.) Hearing set for 12:00. Hearing held at 01:00. Hearing ended at 02:41. Interpreter Marie Hernandez & Edna Brayfield. (amr) (Entered: 06/30/2015)

ORDER as to Carlos Delgado-Vazquez (15). In an effort to gauge whether a finding of excusable neglect or good cause is warranted, it is hereby ordered that First Assistant  Federal Public Defender Hector L. Ramos-Vega apprise the Court as to when Defendant was informed by him of the order denying his motion for sentence reduction, the manner in which this information was provided, and, if this was done in writing, the contents of the notification. Further, it is ordered that the Bureau of Prisons inform the Court of the date in which Defendant received notification of the order denying the motion to reduce sentence. Both Mr. Ramos- Vega and the Bureau of Prisons shall have until 2/23/2016 to file their responses to this order. The Clerk shall notify the Bureau of Prisons of the instant order. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 2/16/2016.(JM) (Entered: 02/16/2016)

ORDER as to Carlos Delgado-Vazquez (15). After analyzing the responses received to the Court's order at Docket No. 1620 , the Court hereby finds good cause and/or excusable neglect to enlarge the time for Petitioner to file his notice of appeal under Federal Rule of Appellate Procedure 4(b). Specifically, Petitioner received notice of the Court's denial of his motion for a sentence reduction under 18 U.S.C. 358(c)(2) on December 28, 2015. Petitioner mailed his notice of appeal on January 11, 2016. Because Petitioner mailed his notice of appeal fewer than fourteen days after he received notice of the denial of his motion, the Court finds good cause and/or excusable neglect to enlarge Petitioner's time to file his notice of appeal. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 3/7/2016. (JM) (Entered: 03/07/2016)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Preliminary Revocation Hearing as to Yaileen Garcia-Santiago (7) held on 3/1/2018. Present: AUSA Cesar Rivera, AFPD Vivianne Marrero and PO Norman Rosario. Defendant was present in court, under custody and assisted by court interpreter Sonia Crescioni. Waiver of preliminary hearing was filed. The Court after advising the defendant as to her rights, approved the waiver and found probable cause as to the allegations contained in the motion filed by the probation officer. Case referred to Judge Dominguez for Final Revocation Hearing. As to bail, defense counsel requested that defendant remain under same conditions of supervised release pending final revocation hearing. The government had no objection that defendant be released but requested that defendant be placed under EMD. The court granted the request. Defendant shall remain under the same conditions of supervised release, but in addition, the court ordered the condition of EMD with home detention. Defendant shall make arrangements to install a landline. Defendant is allowed to work, to go any medical/mental appointments and is also allowed to meet with defense counsel. (Court Reporter DCR.)Hearing set for 10:15.Hearing held at 09:52.Hearing ended at 10:04. Interpreter Sonia Crescioni. (ft) (Entered: 03/01/2018)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Daniel R. Dominguez: Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Yaileen Garcia-Santiago (7) held on 5/17/2018. Present were: SAUSA Camille Garcia for AUSA Rivera, AFPD Vivianne Marrero and USPO Norman Rosario. Defendant present O/B and assisted by the official court interpreter. Defense counsel informed that defendant will not contest the allegation on the motion filed by the U.S. Probation Officer. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment were heard on behalf of defendant. Government's position as to punishment was heard. Defendant's allocution heard. After having heard the parties, the Court found that defendant violated the conditions of supervised release. Therefore, the previously supervised release term is revoked. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Bruce J. McGiverin: Preliminary Revocation Hearing as to Carlos Herrera-Cruz (33) held on 11/4/2019. Present: AUSA Cesar Rivera, AFPD Yasmin Irizarry, USPO David Vazquez. Defendant was U/C, present in court and assisted by a certified court interpreter. AUSA Rivera informed that Jencks material would not be made available until a preliminary hearing was held in local court. He requested that today's hearing be held after the state court hearing. Defense counsel argued in favor of conducting direct testimony today and in favor of setting conditions of release pending the final revocation hearing, as recommended by USPO. The Government did not object to the defendant's release but requested electronic monitoring and an unsecured bond amount. The Court ordered for the defendant to be released under the same conditions of supervised release he's currently under with the added condition of home detention with EM. No financial bail is imposed. Since the defendant will no longer be under custody, the parties agreed that he is not entitled to a preliminary hearing. Therefore, the matter is referred to Judge Daniel R. Dominguez for setting a final revocation hearing. (Court Reporter DCR/ Courtroom 9.) Hearing set for 09:30. Hearing held at 10:09. Hearing ended at 10:17. Interpreter Carlos Ravelo. (bgl) (Entered: 11/04/2019)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marshal D. Morgan: Initial Appearance re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Javier E. Maldonado (32) held on 2/28/2020. Present: AFPD Joannie Plaza on behalf of the defendant. The defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Copies of ECF Nos. 1836 and 1867 were provided to the defendant. The defendant was advised of the alleged SRT violations and also of his rights, including his right to a preliminary hearing. After reviewing the CJA-23 form filed by the defendant, the Court deemed it appropriate to appoint counsel. The Federal Public Defender was appointed to represent the defendant. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marshal D. Morgan:Preliminary Revocation Hearing re 1836 and 1867 Motions Notifying SRT Violations as to Javier E. Maldonado (32) held on 3/5/2020. Present: AUSA Cesar Rivera, AFPD Ivan Santos and USPO Manuel Casanova. The defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. After hearing the defense's arguments as well as briefly conferring with USPO Casanova, AUSA Rivera moved to withdraw the allegation of new criminal conduct related to a domestic violence incident, which was included in Docket No. 1836 . The Court granted the Government's motion and that specific allegation was deemed withdrawn. As to all remaining allegations in Docket Nos. 1836 and 1867 , the defendant filed a Waiver of Preliminary Hearing. The Court approved the waiver and found probable cause pursuant to Rules 5 and 32.1 of the Fed.R.Crim.P. The case was referred to U.S. Senior District Judge Daniel R. Dominguez for Final Revocation Hearing. AFPD Santos argued for conditions of release pending the final hearing. The Government had no objection so long as the defendant remained employed. After having heard the parties, the Court granted the defense's request and ordered the defendant released under the same conditions previously imposed plus the following added conditions: employment or education, drug testing and treatment, and mental health treatment. Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release set for 6/3/2020 10:00 AM in Old San Juan Courtroom before Judge Daniel R. Dominguez. ORDER as to Orlando Herrera-Cruz. Defendant is pending initial appearance and show cause hearing for the alleged supervised release violations informed by the USPO in  Docket No. 1945. The Federal Public Defender is appointed to represent Defendant for the revocation proceedings. Defendant is not entitled to a preliminary revocation hearing as he 1s under conditions of release (see F.R.Cr.P. 32.1(b)(1 )(A)). Defense counsel is encouraged to arrange a client interview by telephone to consider waiving the initial appearance/show cause hearing and to get the waiver signed by Defendant to avoid a VTC. The waiver of the initial appearance/show cause hearing shall be filed by 10/20/2020 and shall state that, pursuant to FRCP 32.1, Defendant was advised of the right to be present during an initial appearance on revocation proceedings; to have a Magistrate Judge inform him of the alleged violations of supervised release; his right to retain counsel or to request that counsel be appointed; his right to a revocation hearing before the District Judge; and upon the advice of counsel Defendant waives the initial appearance/show cause hearing. If the waiver is filed in compliance with the above, the same will be approved and the matter will be referred to the attention of presiding District Judge for a final revocation hearing. In the meantime, Defendant shall continue abiding by all the conditions of his supervised release term. If the waiver is not filed, the initial appearance/show cause hearing will be promptly set via VTC. The Federal Public Defender shall be appointed to represent Defendant for the revocation proceedings. Signed by US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez-Rive on 10/06/2020. (cvr) (Entered: 10/06/2020)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Magistrate Judge Giselle Lopez-Soler: Initial  Appearance re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Angel G. Avillan-Cruz (28) held on 2/16/2021 via VTC. Present was AFPD Eleonora Marranzini. Defendant was present under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Defendant waived his right to appear physically at the hearing and consented to proceed via VTC. Defendant was advised of the SRT violations as alleged in the motion filed at Docket No. 1896 and as to his right to a preliminary hearing to determine whether the supervised release conditions had been violated. Upon the defendant's request, the Court deemed it appropriate to appoint counsel. Defendant will be represented by the FPD's Office. Pursuant to the Due Process Protections Act, Pub. L. ORDER denying 2004 Order on Motion for Compassionate Release - 18 U.S.C. Section 3582(c)(1)(A) as to Juan C. Santiago-Velez (2). Pending before the Court is Juan C. Santiago-Velez's ("Defendant" or "Petitioner") Emergency Motion for Compassionate Release Pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 3582 (c)(1)(A) ("Motion for Compassionate Release"). See Docket No. 2004 . In essence, Defendant requests the Court to reduce his sentence to time served, pursuant to 18 U.S.C.  3582 (c)(1)(A)Q), in attention to the COVID-19 pandemic. Specifically, Petitioner contends that: (1) he has medical conditions - high blood pressure and type-2 diabetes- which place him at risk in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic; (2) he already contracted COVID-19 on December 2020 and continues to experience lingering effects; (3) he has trouble speaking to the medical staff at his facility, since they do not speak Spanish; and (4) he has a valid release plan and does not present a danger to the general population. In opposition, the Government contests that: (1) Petitioner failed to provide evidence to support his allegation related to the exhausted administrative remedies; (2) Defendant failed to provide any evidence as to his medical conditions nor evidence to support the fact that he is not receiving regular medical care; and (3) Defendant does present a risk to the general population. See Docket No. 2007 . After reviewing the Parties' arguments, the Court agrees with the  Government. First, although the Court acknowledges the dangers and challenges that the COVID-19 pandemic has brought upon the Bureau of Prisons ("BOP") and the inmate population, the pandemic -by itself- is not an "extraordinary and compelling" reason to award compassionate release under 18 U.S.C.  3582. See United States v. Raia, 954 F. 3d 594, 597 (3rd Cir. 2020) ("We do not mean to minimize the risks that COVID-19 pose in the federal prison system [...] But the mere existence of COVID-19 in society and the possibility that it may spread to a particular prison alone cannot independently justify compassionate release, especially considering BOP's statutory role, and its extensive and professional efforts to curtail the viruss spread."). On the other hand, the record reveals that Petitioner did not provide any documentation to support his allegations of exhaustion of administrative remedies and underlying health conditions. Finally, the Court highlights that Petitioner plead guilty to charges that identified him as a leader or organizer of a drug point involved with the possession of firearms and possession and distribution of narcotics. Due to the severity of the charges, Petitioner's arguments do not convince the Court that he will not a be a danger to the general population. Considering all of the above, the Court finds that Defendant has failed to meet his burden under 18 U.S.C.  3582 (c)(1)(A)(i). Consequently, his Motion for Compassionate Release is hereby DENIED. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 3/24/2021. (DMA) (Entered: 03/24/2021)

ORDER as to Orlando Herrera-Cruz (29). ORDER denying 2020 Motion for Reconsideration as to Juan C. Santiago- Velez (2). Previously, the Court denied Juan C. Santiago-Velez's ("Defendant") Motion for Compassionate Release. See Docket No. 2012 . Unsatisfied, Defendant filed a Motion for Reconsideration where he alleged that he was providing the Court with a copy of his medical records and the receipt of the denial of his request for compassionate release presented before the Warden; however, Defendant's motion did not include said documents. Nonetheless, the Court notes that unlike the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure do not provide for motions for  reconsideration. In fact, the First Circuit has consistently held that motions for reconsideration in criminal cases are not specifically authorized either by statute or by rule. United States v. Ortiz, 741 F.3d 288, 293 (1st Cir. 2014). If a District Court where to entertain a motion for reconsideration in a criminal procedure, it must apply the standards set for motions for reconsideration under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. See, e.g., United States v. Allen, 573 F.3d 42, 53 (1st Cir. 2009). In said context, [t]he granting of a motion for reconsideration is 'an extraordinary remedy which should be used sparingly." Palmer v. Champion Mortg., 465 F.3d 24, 30 (1st Cir. 2006). "The district court has rather broad authority to grant or to deny such a motion". See United States v. Parcel of Land & Residence Located thereon at 5 Bell Rock Rd., Freetown, Mass., 896 F.2d 605, 611 (1st Cir. 1990); Appeal of Sun Pipe Line Co., 831 F.2d 22, 25 (1st Cir.1987). Furthermore, as to the standard applicable under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, motions for reconsideration are to be entertained by courts if they seek to correct manifest errors of law, present newly discovered evidence, or when there is an intervening change in law. See, e.g., Prescott v. Higgins, 538 F.3d 32, 45 (1st Cir. 2008); Rivera Surillo & Co. v. Falconer Glass Indus., Inc., 37 F.3d 25, 29 (1st Cir. 1994). The Court finds that Defendants Motion falls squarely within the scope of requests that do not warrant reconsideration. Therefore, Defendant's request is hereby DENIED. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 4/28/2021. (DMA) (Entered: 04/28/2021)

MEMORANDUM OF THE CLERK as to Yamil Maldonado-Medina (19): By Order of Judge Daniel R. Dominguez (Docket No. 2037), the 2034 Second Informative Motion Notifying Violations of Supervision Conditions, Requesting a Summons and Order to Show Cause has been randomly referred within the Case Assignment System to Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez-Rive for Show Cause Hearing. Signed by Clerk on 05/19/2021. (ft) (Entered: 05/19/2021)

ORDER as to Yamil Maldonado-Medina. Defendant is pending initial appearance/show cause hearing for the alleged supervised release violations informed by the USPO in Docket No. 2034. The Federal Public Defender is appointed to represent Defendant for the revocation proceedings. Defendant is not entitled to a preliminary revocation hearing as he is under conditions of release (see F.R.Cr.P. 32.1(b)(1)(A)). Defense counsel is encouraged to arrange a client interview by telephone to consider waiving the initial appearance/show cause hearing get the waiver signed by Defendant to avoid a VTC. The waiver of the initial appearance shall be filed by 6/2/2021 and shall state that, pursuant to FRCP 32.1, Defendant was advised of the right to be present during an initial appearance on revocation proceedings; to have a Magistrate Judge inform him of the alleged violations of supervised release; his right to retain counsel or to request that counsel be appointed; his right to a revocation hearing before the District Judge; and upon the advice of counsel Defendant waives the initial appearance. If the waiver is filed in compliance with the above, the same will be approved and the matter will be referred to the attention of presiding District Judge for a final revocation hearing. In the meantime, Defendant shall continue abiding by all the conditions of his supervised release term. If the waiver is not filed, the initial appearance/show cause hearing will be promptly set via VTC. The Federal Public Defender is appointed to represent Defendant for the revocation proceedings. Signed by US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez-Rive on 05/19/2021.(cvr) (Entered: 05/19/2021)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Daniel R. Dominguez: Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Orlando Herrera-Cruz (29) via VTC held on 5/24/2021. Present: AUSA Luis Valentin, AFPD Sulay Rios and USPO Camille Machado. Defendant present, on supervised release and assisted by the official court interpreter. AFPD Rios informed that defendant will not contest the allegations in the motion filed by U.S. Probation Office. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of defendant. Government position as to punishment heard. After having heard the parties, the Court suspended hearing to allow additional drug test from defendant.
